Simple random walk on graph
Example Consider simple random walk on graph G = (V , E) (which is connected). The measure deg(x)(x) = , x 2|E| satises detailed balance equations ; therefore the simple random walk on G is reversible. Hao Wu (MIT) 18.445 18 February 2015 5 / 11

Recall Consider a Markov chain with state space and transition matrix P : P[X n+1 = y | Xn = x] = P(x, y). A probability measure is stationary if = P. If P is irreducible, there exists a unique stationary distribution. Todays goal Ergodic Theorem Time-reversal of Markov chain Birth-and-Death chains Total variation distance Hao Wu (MIT) 18.445 18 February 2015 2 / 11

Random walk on network
Consider a random walk on network (G = (V , E), {c(e) : e E}). Transition matrix : P (x, y) = c(x, y)/c(x) It is reversible The stationary measure : (x) = c(x)/cG. The commute time is dened by ba = min{n b : Xn = a}. Commute Time Identity Ea[ba] = cGR(a b). Assume that the network is transitive, then Ea[b] = Eb[a]. In particular, 2Ea[b] = cGR(a b). Hao Wu (MIT) 18.445 18 March 2015 5 / 9

Estimates on effective resistance
Effective resistance and energy of ows R(a z) = inf{E () : unit ow from a to z}. Corollaries If r(e) r'(e) for all e , we have R(a z; r) R(a z; r'). Upper bound : For any unit ow from a to z, we have R(a z) E(). Lower bound : Nash-William Inequality. { k } are disjoint edge-cut sets which separate a from z , then 1
R(a z) c(e) . k ek Hao Wu (MIT) 18.445 18 March 2015 4 / 9

Three operations Dene the effective resistance between a and z by W (a) W (z)R(a z) = . ||I|| Three operations without changing the effective resistance
Parallel Law : Conductances in parallel add. Series Law : Resistances in series add. Gluing : Identify vertices with the same voltage.
Hao Wu (MIT) 18.445 18 March 2015 3 / 9

Effective Resistance
Consider a network (G = (V , E), {c(e) : e E}).
Suppose that W is a voltage with source a V and sink z V .
Let I be the corresponding current ow : I(xy) = ( W (x) W (y))/r(x, y).
Dene the effective resistance between a and z by
W (a) W (z)R(a z) = . ||I|| Effective resistance and Escape probability 1Pa[z < +] = .a c(a)R(a z) Effective resistance and Greens function Gz (a, a) = c(a)R(a z). Hao Wu (MIT) 18.445 18 March 2015 2 / 9
18.445 Introduction to Stochastic Processes Lecture 11: Summary on random walks on network Hao Wu MIT 18 March 2015 Hao Wu (MIT) 18.445 18 March 2015 1 / 9

Random walk on binary tree
A tree is a connected graph with no cycles.
A rooted tree has a distinguished vertex v 0, called the root.
The depth of a vertex v is its graph distance to the root.
A leaf is a vertex with degree one. A rooted binary tree of depth k, denoted by T 2 k , is a tree with a root v0
such that
v0 has degree 2. For 1 j k 1, every vertex at
distance j from the root has
degree 3.
The vertices at distance k from
the root are leaves (they have degree 1).
18.445 18 March 2015 6 / 9 Hao Wu (MIT)

About this course Coupon collecting
The collectors situation can be modeled by a Markov chain on the state space {0, 1, ..., N} : X0 = 0 Xn : the number of different types among the collectors rst n coupons. P[X n+1 = k + 1 | Xn = k] = (N k)/N, P[X n+1 = k | Xn = k] = k/N. : the rst time that the collector obtains all N types. Hao Wu (MIT) 18.445 04 February 2015 9 / 15

About this course Todays goal
1 2 3 4 Denitions Gamblers ruin coupon collecting stationary distribution Hao Wu (MIT) 18.445 04 February 2015 4 / 15 1 2 3 4

About this course Coupon collecting
A company issues N different types of coupons. A collector desires a
complete set.
Question : How many coupons must he obtain so that his collection contains all N types. Assumption : each coupon is equally likely to be each of the N types.
Hao Wu (MIT) 18.445 04 February 2015 8 / 15

About this course Grading Grading : 5 Homeworks (10% each) Midterm (15%, April 1st.) Final (35%, May) Homeworks : Homeworks will be collected at the end of the class on the due date. Due dates : Feb. 23rd, Mar. 9th, Apr. 6th, Apr. 22nd, May. 4th Collaboration on homework is encouraged. Individually written solutions are required. Exams : The midterm and the nal are closed book, closed notes, no calculators. Hao Wu (MIT) 18.445 04 February 2015 3 / 15

About this course Gamblers ruin The gamblers situation can be modeled by a Markov chain on the state space {0, 1, ..., N} : X0 : initial money in purse Xn : the gamblers fortune at time n P[X n+1 = Xn + 1 | Xn] = 1/2, P[X n+1 = Xn 1 | Xn] = 1/2. The states 0 and N are absorbing. : the time that the gambler stops. Answer to the questions Theorem Hao Wu (MIT) 18.445 04 February 2015 7 / 15 Assume that X 0 = k for some 0 k N. Then kP[X = N] = , E[] = k(N k).N
18.445 Introduction to Stochastic Processes Lecture 1: Introduction to nite Markov chains Hao Wu MIT 04 February 2015 Hao Wu (MIT) 18.445 04 February 2015 1 / 15

About this course Gamblers ruin
Consider a gambler betting on the outcome of a sequence of
independent fair coin tosses. If head, he gains one dollar. If tail, he loses one dollar. If he reaches a fortune of N dollars, he stops.
If his purse is ever empty, he stops.
Questions : What are the probabilities of the two possible fates ? How long will it take for the gambler to arrive at one of the two possible fates ? Hao Wu (MIT) 18.445 04 February 2015 6 / 15

About this course Course description
Course description : This course is an introduction to Markov chains, random walks, martingales. Time and place : Course : Monday and Wednesday, 11 :00 am-12 :30pm. Bibliography : Markov Chains and Mixing Times, by David A. Levin, Yuval Peres, Elizabeth L. Wilmer Hao Wu (MIT) 18.445 04 February 2015 2 / 15

About this course Random walks on graphs Denition Denition 04 February 2015 14 / 15 Hao Wu (MIT) 18.445 A graph G = (V , E) consists of a vertex set V and an edge set E : V : set of vertices E : set of pairs of vertices When (x, y) E, we write x y : x and y are joined by an edge. We say y is a neighbor of x . ( ) : For x V , deg x the number of neighbors of x . Given a graph G = (V , E), we dene simple random walk on G to be the Markov chain with state space V and transition matrix :
1/deg (x) if y xP(x, y) = . 0 else

About this course : nite state space P : transition matrix |||| Denition Hao Wu (MIT) 18.445 04 February 2015 5 / 15 A sequence of random variables (X 0, X1, X2, ...) is a Markov chain with state space and transition matrix P if for all n 0, and all sequences (x 0, x1, ..., xn, xn+1), we have that P[X n+1 = xn+1 | X0 = x0, ..., Xn = xn] = P[X n+1 = xn+1 | Xn = xn] = P(xn, xn+1).

Question Suppose that a martingale Xis bounded in L1, then we have the a.s. convergence. Question : Do we have E[X1] =E[X 0]? Answer : It is true when we have convergence in L1. Recurrence Suppose that Xis a continuous time Markov chain and that Yis its jump chain. Denition A state xis recurrent if Px[ft:Xt=xgis unbounded] = 1. A state xis transient if Px[ft:Xt=xgis unbounded] <1. Theorem Let X be an irreducible continuous time Markov chain. If x is recurrent for Y , then x is recurrent for X. If x is transient for Y , then x is transient for X. Either all states are recurrent, or all states are transient. R Remark A state xis recurrent for Xif and only if1 0Pt(x;xR)dt=1. A state xis transient for Xif and only if1 0Pt(x;x)dt<1. Hao Wu (MIT) 18.445 11 May 2015 5 / 5

Voltage Denition Consider a network (G= (V;E);fc(e) :e2Eg). We distinguish two vertices a(the source) and z(the sink). A voltage is a function on V which is harmonic on Vnfa;zg. Remark A voltage is completely determined by its boundary values W(a)andW(z). Hao Wu (MIT) 18.445 09 March 2015 6 / 10

Network Denition A network is a nite undirected connected graph G= (V;E)endowed with non-negative numbers fc(e) :e2Eg. c(e): conductance. Write c(x;y)forc(e)where e=fx;yg. Clearly c(x;y) =c(y;x). r(e) =1=c(e): resistance. Hao Wu (MIT) 18.445 09 March 2015 3 / 10

Rooted trees Atree is a connected graph with no cycles. Arooted tree has a distinguished vertex v0, called the root. Thedepth of a vertex vis its graph distance to the root. Aleafis a vertex with degree one. Consider a regular rooted tree : each vertex has a xed number (say m) of offspring Zn:the number vertices in the n-th generation A rooted binary tree for regular tree : Zn=mn In real life, we often encounter trees where the number of offspring of a vertex is random. Hao Wu (MIT) 18.445 27 April 2015 2 / 7

Recall Consider a Markov chain with state space and transition matrix P : P[X n+1 = y | Xn = x] = P(x, y). 0 : the distribution of X 0; n : the distribution of X n. We call a probability measure is stationary if = P. If is stationary and 0 = , then n = , n. Todays goal Irreducible, aperiodic existence and uniqueness of stationary distribution. Hao Wu (MIT) 18.445 17 February 2015 2 / 7
MIT OpenCourseWare http://ocw.mit.edu 18.445 Introduction to Stochastic Processes Spring 2015 For information about citing these materials or our Terms of Use, visit: http://ocw.mit.edu/terms .

Summary about stationary distribution
In the proof of the existence and the uniqueness of stationary distribution, the crucial assumption is that P is irreducible. When P is irreducible, we can explicitly write out the stationary distribution 1 (x) = > 0, x . Ex [+]x In fact, the existence does not require irreducibility, but the uniqueness does. Hao Wu (MIT) 18.445 17 February 2015 7 / 7
